title: Electric force - 2 hanging spheres charge and mass

content.question: Two charged spheres, Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> and Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, are hanging at rest and are suspended from insulating stands by insulating strings, as shown in the figure. The spheres have the same diameter but different masses. Since the spheres are both charged, the strings do not hang vertically. The string supporting Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> makes a greater angle from the vertical than the string supporting Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. Which of the following claims is correct about the charges on and the masses of the two spheres?

choices.label: The charges have the same sign, and Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> has a greater mass than Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

The charges have the same sign, and Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> has a greater mass than Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>.

The charges are of opposite sign, and Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> has a greater mass than Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.

The charges are of opposite sign, and Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> has a greater mass than Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>.

content.answer: The charges are of opposite sign, and Sphere <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> has a greater mass than Sphere <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>.
